result.execSummary:
The defendant John A Shepard was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).
  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Def to sign up for Probation today
.

miscConds.notes:
No Contact with the victim T.J.
.

Complete any assessments or evaluations PO deems necessary and follow-through with any treatment recommended

Court costs/fees are REMITTED by the Court due to indigence EXCEPT Def is to pay $100 Domestic Abuse Surcharge on Each count ($200 total)

All Court-ordered financial obligations shall be paid directly to the La Crosse County Clerk of Court.  If the defendant is not able to pay the amount in full, payment plan is $25 per month with the first payment due 10-1-2022 and each subsequent payment will be due the 1st of each month thereafter until paid in full.  Failure to pay will result in a Judgment being entered and collected by WI State Debt Collections

Pay DOC Supervision fees - to be paid directly to the Dept of Corrections

Credit for 44 days if probation is ever revoked
.

supervisions.notes:
